title: For Sale:  Smith& Wesson .38 Safety Haammerless
location: Santa Fe, NM, New Mexico, United States
postcontent:
Also known as the "Lemon Squeezer". This handgun is in NRA Excellent condition (80% original finish or greater) and has a pretty uncommon combination of being a .38 S&W with 4 inch barrel. Most of these were only .32s, and most had a shorter 3 inch barrel. Not exactly a rare combination, but you certainly don't see them like this very often. Its original Gutta Perchas grips are perfect with no chips or cracks. It was made in the 1930s, so it has S&W's Pre-War quality and you can tell it when you look at it. Although this is in collectible condition, this would still make a viable  handgun for self defense. It is DA only, has a grip safety, and is small enough and safe enough to slip into a jacket pocket.  There is no hammer to snag and the grip safety renders it perfectly safe in a pocket, unlike most modern firearms. It can even be fired from INSIDE a pocket! (But don't do that...) The topbreak design ejects all five rounds instantly when it is opened. Sounds like Smith or Ruger should be making one just like it today. But they don't.

That said, this isn't a Glock and has its limitations. The rear sight is small and if you want to use it you will definitely have to get used to that. The front sight is quite visible however, and it points instinctively. All this talk about shooting is kind of misses the point of the gun though. These are very collectible and would be considered to be a good investment in this condition. If you have read this far, you probably already know that. The .38 S&W round was the British WWII service round, and it proved to be a good manstopper for them They kept it in service for well over 50 years and in some country it is still being used today.

By now, most of these Safety Hammerless revolvers are rusty, pitted, or have been refinished. This one is all original with just a superb bore and is and tight as the day it was made when Franklin Roosevelt was president. Pretty cool considering it was actually designed before Teddy Roosevelt was President! These guns were hand fitted and finished, and S&W stopped making them after WWII because it was just too expensive to make. When you hold it in your hand you will see that.

I am on the low end of the scale for one of these in this condition. I see them on Gunbroker going for more with pits or refinished or mismatched. Check them out and compare. I did before I wrote this so I already know what you are going to see there, lol. This one is a nice revolver, and I think you would be proud to own it.

It is classified as a C&R by the ATF, so if you live too far away I can ship it to an FFL03 address. Just contact me and we can make arrangements. Shipping would run about $35.

I can be reached via email through Armslist. I used to put my phone number and email address in these ads but I was bombarded by Nigerian princes who wanted to make me rich. If you are a Nigerian prince, don't bother unless you can buy the gun face to face and are legal to do so in the US. (Unlikely, huh?)

So thanks for reading my long winded ad. When you see this S&W you will not be disappointed.

The rail is equipped with iron sights that are simple in design, but are not user friendly in their adjustment. The sight rail has numerous positions available for the installation of optical sights and other devices.
